bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, January 8, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] asks that the Public Health Service supervise mosquito study and control of ponds at Badin and other places in North Carolina.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, January 8, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
N. M. C
Imp'd water
Fricks
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
January 8, 1922.
Surgeon L. D. Fricks,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House Building,
Memphis, Tonn.
Dear Doctor Fricks:
div1.p:
I Mr. Thorpe, the General Manager of the plant of the American
Aluminum Co. at Badin, N. C., was in to see me a few days ago.
He is desireous of carrying out such measures as are necessary
and possible for the control of malaria caused by the Badin Pond.

He asked if I would be willing to undertake the general super-
vision of this and to recommend someone who could give it the ne-
cessary attention on the ground. It seemed to me better for him,
however, if someone from the Malaria Division of the Service could
be detailed for both the general and local supervision--not taking
up all of their time upon this job, but visiting it from time to
time, so as to see that their plans are carried out, and--naturally--
varying these plans as conditions of weather etc. may require.
The actual expense of carrying out these measures would, of course,
be borne by the Power Company.

Should you find it advisable to undertake this work for the
Malaria Division, and should you so wish. I will be very willing to
visit the place two, three or four times the next summer for the
sake of consulting with your representative. Mr. Thorpe would pay
travelling expenses for so doing & there would of course, be no charges for services.

This would be--if it be feasible--a good opportunity
opportunity

1/ For research on a pond filled in 1916, part of which was per-
fectly cleared: part of which partly, and part not cleared at all.
The biological and epidemiological examination then, could be made to
cover three conditions of pond preparation with less expenditure of
time and effort than one would be apt to have elsewhere.

2/ One would have an opportunity to observe the effect of sani-
tary measures in preventing mosquito breeding under, I think, unusually
favorable conditions--I don't mean for success especially, but for de-
termination. The Manager of the Company is a man of unusual abili-
ty: force and good feeling and I think ordersadvice will be carried out and
co-operation given in a way that one would not find in many places.

This place is convenient to Charlotte--about two hours run by au-
to--has machines: a good steam launch and small boats for towing: one
man at least, who has had some training in malaria control and in rais-
ing Gambusia: and a successful Gambusia nursery.

There would, of course, be no difficulty in getting Dr. Rankin to
make the request on you should you be willing to grant it.

As I said, I think it would be better for Mr. Thorpe for this work
to be under the supervision of the Service, yet, if you do not think it
possible to undertake it, I can--I am quite certain--get Boldridge, of
Chester, S. C., who has done some pond work with me, to take charge of it.

II) I wrote you a letter--in early October, I think, relative to the
chances of taking up this problem of impounded waters in some of the pro-
jects of the Southern Power Company. I do not know whether they applied
to you or not. Before you could agree, this too, of course, would have
to come from Dr. Rankin. I have no copy of the letter I wrote you, as
it was in script, but my recollection is that it went into the question
in some detail and suggested that if you stationed your representative at
at
3.
Charlotte, he could begin with the survey of the Mountain Island Pond,
close to Charlotte, which will be filled next fall and on which I, my-
self, outlined in some detail the preliminary work necessary, and had
made a survey of one of its principal valleys.

That I thought he would have time enough next year to make such
other biological surveys as were needed to establish the status of the
great Bridgewater Pond as to the production of Anopheles--a thing that
is in question. Whether he could do this and also do the research and
supervision necessary at Badin may be a question. I think I could have
done so a few years ago. If it be advisable to conduct research in
these three places and one man be unable to do it, all, I presume another
man could be temporarily assigned in the Bridgewater matter--provided
that you considered it more advantageous to make the research at Badin
than at Bridgewater.

In case you cannot do the examination needed at Bridgewater, I, at
present, purpose to complete it as far as may be necessary myself. I
have been on the Pond three times already and I think two more trips of
--say--14 days each--or may be better, three of 10 days each--next sum-
mer should be sufficient.

Griffitts would seem to me the man best suited and available for
this work. LePrince is absolutely suited, but I don't consider it con-
ceivable that you could spare him for it and xx Griffitts is the only other
man who has had any experience in this class of research. Also from one
aspect of it at least, a physician and a bench man is needed. advisable. alth
